Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diagnosing the Timing and Drivers of Northeastern Caribbean Holocene Droughts with Sinkhole Lake Records
Award.AbstractNarration:
This century, 80% of the world could face insufficient water necessary for food production, energy and national security, human health, and ecosystems. The United Nations estimates that Caribbean losses related to climate change by 2080 will be $11.2B, with $3.8B from drought. Rainfall in the Caribbean and American southeast is linked to similar ocean and atmospheric factors. However, geologic records of rainfall document extreme Caribbean megadroughts lasting tens to hundreds of years over the last several millennia. This project aims to identify and communicate the causes and drivers of these megadroughts through research and teaching American students at 3 institutions. It will help the United States, developing nations, and small island nations mitigate future water security risks.

Climate model forecasts of rainfall changes in the American southeast and Caribbean for this century are currently equivocal, and available paleoclimate archives from the Caribbean document extreme megadroughts with a severity not observed in the instrumental era. These droughts were apparently not uniform across the Caribbean, and their causes remain poorly understood. Here, the investigators propose to develop a network of long-term rainfall records from key portions of the northern Caribbean using established geologic techniques and state-of-the-art climate modeling to diagnose the climatic drivers of Caribbean droughts.

This award is cofunded by the Paleo Perspectives on Climate Change Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sediment records from sinkhole ponds in the Bahamas and Caicos were used to reconstruct past changes in environmental conditions. In particular, we looked at evidence of changes in environment that reflected variability in moisture availability. In total, the various reconstructions point to episodic drought punctuating the last 5000 years including a megadrought which occurred between 3300 and 2500 years ago. The megadrought was likely caused by a southern displacement of the subtropical high in the North Atlantic, which would have increased the exposure of the northeastern Caribbean region to subsiding dry air. Given model projections for intensification and displacement of the NASH during this century, the megadrought from 3300 to 2500 years ago may provide an important prehistoric analog for future regional water stress scenarios.

Sediment cores from Washing Pond on Caicos Island reveal at least three relatively short lived (decadal scale) drought events which date to 1520-1530, 1000-1020 and 190-210 CE. Charcoal pieces preserved in the sediments provide a history of local fire on the landscape surrounding Washing Pond spanning the last 1800 years. A dramatic rise in charcoal ca. 545 CE likely indicates the arrival of humans on the island. Relatively high abundances of charcoal persist until the very early 16th century CE when they once again return to pre 545 CE levels. This very low level of charcoal influx to Washing Pond continued until the late 18th century when British loyalists from America settled on the island after the American Revolution. The lack of charcoal in the sediments in the 17th and much of the 18th century reflects the fact that indigenous people on the island were absent after European contact, likely reflecting mortality to European diseases.

Fossil pollen and charcoal from sediments in Blackwood Sinkhole, Abaco provide a similar record. From about 3000 to 1000 years ago, coppice forests dominated by hardwoods and palms were resilient to the effects of hurricanes and cooling regional sea surface temperatures. The arrival of Lucayan people about 830 CE is demarcated by increased burning, and soon followed by landscape disturbance and a time-transgressive shift from coppice to the modern pine forest. While pre-contact landscapes would have been influenced by storms and climatic trends, the most pronounced changes at Blackwood Sinkhole follow more directly from landscape burning and ecosystem shifts following Lucayan arrival. We also discovered human Lucayan remains (human tibia) in a core from Great Cistern Sinkhole on Abaco. Radiocarbon dates indicate that the remains date to between 1255 and 1340 CE. The pine forests of Abaco significantly declined due to increased regional hurricane activity between about 1500 and 1670 CE coupled with fires on an already human-impacted landscape. Any future increase in intense hurricane activity in the tropical North Atlantic Ocean threatens the sustainability of modern forests in the northern Bahamas.
